channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Postcard from Solomon Islands: The legacy of RAMSI
item.description: More than two decades on, what are the lasting effects of a mission to save a failing state?

item.title: Miami elects a new mayor at a pivotal moment
item.description: Her challenge is to make dizzying growth last

item.title: U.S. Farmers Aren’t Out of the Woods Yet
item.description: Trump’s bailout offers temporary relief, but trade war pain remains.

item.title: Iain Douglas-Hamilton, the scientist who saved the elephants
item.description: The beasts have lost their stoutest defender

item.title: The IMF's balancing act in Papua New Guinea
item.description: The IMF reform program is making welcome and unexpected progress, but the hardest work still lies ahead.

item.title: Zelensky Defies U.S. Pressure to Cede Territory to Russia
item.description: The White House has suggested that Moscow will likely win the Russia-Ukraine war.

item.title: Dirty Air Threatens India’s Global Power
item.description: How New Delhi’s pollution has become a more fundamental crisis.

item.title: What’s worse for innovation: MAGA or Mao?
item.description: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping share a dangerous nostalgia

item.title: A Bad Week for Washington’s China Hawks
item.description: Trump’s overtures to Beijing deal a blow to U.S. hard-liners.

item.title: Trump Threatens Mexico With Tariffs Over Water
item.description: Drought has dried up Mexico’s water supply, much to the chagrin of Texas farmers—and Trump.

item.title: The Treason of the Populists
item.description: The modern media landscape has given far-right "thinkers" a salience beyond their wildest dreams, reflected in the new US National Security Strategy. But their pseudo-intellectualism will never pass as the real thing, and while they may court the working class, it is financiers and tech billionaires whose interests they serve.

item.title: Donald Trump is tearing up America’s chip-control policy
item.description: His administration wants China hooked on American technology. China has other ideas

item.title: Donald Trump’s flawed plan to get China hooked on Nvidia chips
item.description: The president is tearing up America’s export-control policy

item.title: MAGA’s man in LatAm
item.description: Fernando Cerimedo has run right-wing campaigns across Latin America, forging close ties with MAGA and Donald Trump

item.title: Trump Is Betting Against the Future
item.description: The new US National Security Strategy bears the cognitive signature of a movement that experiences demographic and cultural change as existential catastrophe. The goal is not merely to ignore real threats but to redefine the threat itself as the presence of people President Donald Trump calls “garbage.”

item.title: Kambarata-1 to See Joint Financing From Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan in 2026
item.description: 2026 looks to be a pivotal year in which the trilateral hydropower project will either make serious steps forward or languish, as previous efforts have, in the void between ambition and reality.

item.title: All Cash-Strapped Governments Should Be Using this Tool
item.description: By engaging in outcomes-based partnerships, governments can advance social-policy goals at half the cost, while paying only when targets have been achieved. Better yet, such initiatives can be scaled up massively, because they offer precisely the kind of opportunities that socially minded investors have been seeking.

item.title: France Didn’t Lose the Sahel—Everyone Did
item.description: Blaming Paris for Mali’s problems won’t solve them. A collective European response is needed.

item.title: China raises the cost of Indonesia’s neutrality
item.description: Far from mere choreography, Beijing is shaping Jakarta’s growth agenda to suit its future core interests.

item.title: South Korea’s Unification Minister Is Not Happy With DMZ Administration
item.description: While Chung Dong-young’s political agenda is clear, his comments fail to recognize that the DMZ is governed by specific rules and procedures for important reasons.

item.title: The Roots of Britain’s Economic Malaise
item.description: There are five issues that any UK government must address in order to bring about a robust economic recovery, beginning with launching a process to rejoin the European single market or customs union. But rationalizing spending on the National Health Service, pensions, and welfare benefits will require considerably more courage.

item.title: India and the Indo-Pacific in Trump’s Second-term Strategy
item.description: The new National Security Strategy offers important insights into how a second Trump presidency views the Indo-Pacific and the role India is expected to play within it.

item.title: The Problem With Taiwan’s $40 Billion Defense Budget
item.description: The defense spending hike is a necessary step, but it avoids harder questions.

item.title: 100 Ships at Sea: Strategic Observations on the Chinese Navy’s 2025 Winter Exercises
item.description: The PLAN’s deployments – the biggest to date – stretched from the southern Yellow Sea through the East and South China Seas and deep into the Western Pacific.

item.title: Putin’s India Visit Reveals New Delhi’s Complicated Strategy
item.description: Amid difficult relations with the U.S., India is keen to show that it has other options.

item.title: Europe’s Electric Straitjacket
item.description: Reaching climate neutrality by 2050 is non-negotiable, but it is impossible to know in 2025 the best way to get there. Rather than attempt to dictate the pathway now, EU policymakers must design a strategy that leaves space for unexpected innovations and adequately accounts for geopolitical risk.

item.title: China’s Diplomatic Machinery Is Wearing Thin
item.description: China’s foreign policy bureaucracy faces a mounting succession crisis that will only multiply in 2026.

item.title: Netflix and Paramount are battling for more than just Warner Bros
item.description: They present rival visions for the future of entertainment

item.title: Unpacking the Local Impact of China’s Mega-Projects on Kyrgyzstan’s Regions
item.description: Too often opportunities concentrate within capital cities or designated special economic zones, and thereby render the rest of the country peripheral.

item.title: Postcolonial Chicken
item.description: The U.S. introduced fast food to the Philippines. Now Jollibee is serving it back to America.

item.title: Trump’s Pardon Racket
item.description: The pardon power is the only authority the US Constitution places entirely in the president’s hands, immune from legislative override or judicial review. For Alexander Hamilton, who assumed that shame would restrain abuse, Donald Trump is the nightmare scenario.

item.title: Vietnam Tries to Escape the U.S.-China Trap
item.description: Hanoi has been quietly expanding partnerships beyond the Indo-Pacific.

item.title: Vietnam’s 2026 Budget, Explained
item.description: Strong economic performance sent government revenue soaring in 2025, putting the country in an enviable fiscal position.

item.title: Nagaland Wants Unrestricted Entry of Foreign Nationals to Boost Tourism
item.description: Unlike Nagaland, Manipur and Mizoram are not opposed to the Protected Area Permit given their concerns over the influx of refugees and rebels from Myanmar.

item.title: Why Richard Nixon Killed National Child Care
item.description: The president’s veto had to do with mounting opposition to his policy of detente.

item.title: How China Wins the Future
item.description: Beijing’s strategy to seize the new frontiers of power.

item.title: Compute Is the New Oil
item.description: America and the Gulf must work together on artificial intelligence.

item.title: Putin and Modi Affirm Russia-India Defense Relations
item.description: Three major areas of strategic concern were discussed in Delhi: defense purchases, nuclear power generation and space technology.

item.title: Chinese Court Orders Malaysia Airlines to Pay Compensation Over Missing Flight MH370
item.description: With the search for MH370 set to resume on December 30, China has approved its first compensation claim involving the doomed aircraft.

item.title: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: then, now and into the future
item.description: DFAT has evolved to be more diverse – but is it equipped to face the challenges of a multipolar world?
